data.question: What is the chemical formula for MOF-14?
data.answer: Cu3(BTB)2(H2O)3z(DMF)9(H2O)2

data.question: What is the diameter of the large pores in MOF-14?
data.answer: 16.4 angstroms

data.question: What method was used to pattern surface free energies inside microchannel networks?
data.answer: Combining multistream liquid laminar flow and self-assembled monolayer (SAM) chemistry

data.question: What is the role of the P-minimal surface in the structure of MOF-14?
data.answer: It partitions space into two interpenetrating labyrinths, each consisting of six orthogonal channels meeting at sites of a primitive cubic lattice.

data.question: How does MOF-14 maintain its structural integrity in solution?
data.answer: Guest exchange studies indicate that MOF-14 maintains its structural integrity in solution.

data.question: What is the maximum pressure determined by in the surface-directed liquid flow inside microchannels?
data.answer: The maximum pressure is determined by the surface free energy of the liquid, the advancing contact angle of the liquid on the hydrophobic regions, and the channel depth.

data.question: What happens to MOF-14 under 1025 torr at room temperature after 40 hours?
data.answer: A weight loss of 38.5% was observed, equivalent to the loss of virtually all guests.

data.question: Why are the pores in MOF-14 considered exceptionally large?
data.answer: Because a sphere 16.4 Å in diameter can fit inside each cavity, which is substantially larger than that of noninterpenetrated MOFs.

data.question: How does the interweaving structure of MOF-14 contribute to its stability?
data.answer: The interweaving allows mutual reinforcement of the exceptionally large BTB moieties, which alone would be insufficiently rigid to sustain an open framework.

data.question: What is the significance of the gas sorption isotherms for MOF-14?
data.answer: They confirm the rigidity and permanent porosity of the evacuated framework.

data.question: How does the synthesis of MOF-14 involve copper(II) nitrate?
data.answer: Copper(II) nitrate reacts with H3BTB in a solvent mixture to produce MOF-14.

data.question: What is the effect of the virtual walls in the microchannel networks?
data.answer: They confine liquid flow to hydrophilic pathways, creating a large gas-liquid interface.

data.question: Is MOF-14 stable in air?
data.answer: True

data.question: Does MOF-14 lose its structural integrity when immersed in an organic solvent?
data.answer: False

data.question: Are the pores in MOF-14 smaller than those in MOF-5?
data.answer: False

data.question: Can MOF-14 sorb voluminous amounts of gases and organic solvents reversibly?
data.answer: True

data.question: Is the evacuated MOF-14 unstable at temperatures below 250°C?
data.answer: False

data.question: Do the gas sorption isotherms for MOF-14 show hysteresis upon desorption of gases from the pores?
data.answer: False

data.question: Is the surface-directed liquid flow technique used to create pressure-insensitive switches inside channel networks?
data.answer: False

data.question: Does MOF-14 have a smaller pore volume compared to the most porous crystalline zeolites?
data.answer: False
